channel.title: Comments on: Cache Hits in Web Browsers

item.title: By: Another http traffic debugger
item.dc:creator: Another http traffic debugger
item.description: There are some other good http traffic debuggers. For example http debugger ($50) http://www.httpdebugger.com/ or fiddler (free) http://www.fiddlertool.org./
item.content:encoded:
There are some other good http traffic debuggers.
For example http debugger ($50) http://www.httpdebugger.com/ or fiddler (free) http://www.fiddlertool.org/.

item.title: By: Kristian
item.dc:creator: Kristian
item.description: In firebug you can check if elements is cached in the Net tab. The color of the bar indicates if the element is cached or not - dark gray = not cached, light gray = from cache. You can also check the content-length in the response header.
item.content:encoded: In firebug you can check if elements is cached in the Net tab. The color of the bar indicates if the element is cached or not – dark gray = not cached, light gray = from cache. You can also check the content-length in the response header.

item.title: By: Ian
item.dc:creator: Ian
item.description:
I just purchased a plugin for IE to do this. It's pricey but it does work very well.
http://www.httpwatch.com/
It also works with ajax requests which is what I primarily use it for along with checking if my JS includes are coming from cache or not since getting that working right on IE is a pain.
item.content:encoded:
I just purchased a plugin for IE to do this. It’s pricey but it does work very well.

http://www.httpwatch.com/

It also works with ajax requests which is what I primarily use it for along with checking if my JS includes are coming from cache or not since getting that working right on IE is a pain.
